content: New Zealand's parliament building, The Beehive, was officially opened in 1981
- Ancestors of the Maori arrive by canoe from other parts of Polynesia. Their name for the country is Aotearoa (land of the long white cloud).
- Dutch explorer Abel Tasman sights the south island and charts some of the country's west coast. It subsequently appears on Dutch maps as Nieuw Zeeland, named after the Dutch province of Zeeland.
- British captain James Cook explores coastline, also in 1773 and 1777.
- First British missionaries arrive.
- Treaty of Waitangi between British and several Maori tribes pledges protection of Maori land and establishes British law in New Zealand.
- The New Zealand Wars, also referred to as the Land Wars. Maori put up resistance to British colonial rule.
- New Zealand becomes world's first country to give women the vote.
- Government introduces old-age pensions.
- New Zealand becomes dominion within British Empire.
- Outbreak of World War I. New Zealand commits thousands of troops to the British war effort. They suffer heavy casualties in the Gallipoli campaign in Turkey in 1915.
- Troops from New Zealand see action in Europe, North Africa and the Pacific during World War II.
- New Zealand gains full independence from Britain.
- Troops from New Zealand serve with UN forces in the 1950-53 Korean War.
- Anzus Pacific security treaty signed between New Zealand, Australia and USA.
- New Zealand sends a small combat force to support US troops in Vietnam.
- Labour government elected, Prime Minister David Lange begins radical free-market economic reforms.
- New Zealand refuses to allow US nuclear-powered or nuclear-armed ships to enter its ports.
French secret service agents blow up Greenpeace ship Rainbow Warrior in Auckland Harbour. One person killed.
- US suspends its Anzus obligations towards New Zealand.
- Opposition National Party wins election, James Bolger becomes prime minister.
- Under new proportional representation electoral system, number of Maori MPs rises from six to 15.
- James Bolger resigns after leadership challenge, and Jenny Shipley becomes New Zealand's first woman prime minister.
- Waitangi Tribunal orders government to return confiscated land in Turangi Township to its Maori owners.
- New Zealand troops join a UN peacekeeping force in East Timor.
- Labour Party wins election. Helen Clark becomes prime minister.
May - Intense debate over proposed bill to nationalise sea bed. Maori protesters say bill would infringe ancestral rights. Government survives no-confidence vote.
October - Police arrest 17 people in anti-terror raids. Prosecutors accuse Maori activists of planning a violent campaign against the country's white majority.
November - John Key leads the centre-right National Party to victory in a general election.
June - New Zealand's economy shrinks for the fifth consecutive quarter, making it officially the longest recession in the country's history.
August - New Zealand sends about 70 elite SAS troops to Afghanistan for the third time at the request of the United States.
October - Labour laws amended to help ensure that two big-budget films of the novel The Hobbit are made in New Zealand.
February - Scores of people are killed in a major earthquake in Christchurch, New Zealand's second-largest city, on South Island.
April - New Zealand becomes the first country in the Asia-Pacific region to legalise same-sex marriage.
- Two powerful earthquakes rock central New Zealand including the capital, Wellington, but without causing major damage.
- A 6.3 magnitude earthquake rattles New Zealand's North Island, but without causing major damage or serious injury.
December - Bill English becomes prime minister after John Key quits unexpectedly.

March - A river revered by the Maori people becomes the first in the world to be recognised as a living entity with the same legal rights as a person, after parliament passes a bill granting the Whanganui River special status.
May - A New Zealand-American company, Rocket Lab, launches its first test rocket into space, ushering New Zealand into the select group of countries which have carried out a space launch.
October - Inconclusive parliamentary elections. Labour's Jacinda Ardern forms coalition government.
March - Fifty people are killed when a far-right gunman attacks worshippers in two mosques in Christchurch. Government tightens gun laws.
October - Jacinda Ardern wins landslide victory for Labour in parliamentary elections, in part over her handling of the Covid-19 pandemic.
